current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To establish the Surface Transportation Board as an independent establishment, and for other
			 purposes.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

action-instruction.#text: Strike out all after the enacting clause and insert the part printed in italic

short-title.#text: Surface Transportation Board Reauthorization Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

Except as otherwise expressly provided, wherever in this Act an amendment or repeal is expressed in
			 terms of an amendment to, or repeal of, a section or other provision, the
			 reference shall be considered to be made to a section or other provision
			 of title 49, United States Code.

header.#text: References to title 49, United States Code
Establishment of Surface Transportation Board as an independent establishment

text.#text: Section 701(a) is amended to read as follows:
The Surface Transportation Board is an independent establishment of the United States Government.
Section 703 is amended—
by striking subsections (a), (c), (f), and (g);
by redesignating subsections (b), (d), and (e) as subsections (a), (b), and (c), respectively; and
by adding at the end the following:

Whenever the Board submits or transmits any budget estimate, budget request, supplemental budget
			 estimate, or other budget information, legislative recommendation,
			 prepared testimony for a congressional hearing, or comment on legislation
			 to the President or to the Office of Management and Budget, it shall
			 concurrently transmit a copy thereof to the Committee on Commerce,
			 Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on
			 Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives. No
			 officer or agency of the United States shall have any authority to require
			 the Board to submit its budget estimates or requests, legislative
			 recommendations, prepared testimony for congressional hearings, or
			 comments on legislation to any officer or agency of the United States for
			 approval, comments, or review, prior to the submission of the
			 recommendations, testimony, or comments to Congress.
Section 725 is repealed.
The table of contents for chapter 7 is amended by striking the item relating to section 725.
Section 701(b) is amended—
in paragraph (1)—
by striking
by striking
by striking paragraph (2) and inserting the following:

At any given time, at least 3 members of the Board shall be individuals with professional standing
			 and demonstrated knowledge in the fields of transportation, transportation
			 regulation, or economic regulation, and at least 2 members shall be
			 individuals with professional or business experience (including
			 agriculture or other rail customers) in the private sector.

quote.#text: qualified, but for a period not to exceed one year

each individual present at the meeting is a member or an employee of the Board; and

of title 5, a majority of the members may hold a

a summary of the matters discussed at the meeting, except for any matters the

			 place easily accessible to the public—

If a discussion under subparagraph (A) relates, directly or indirectly, to an ongoing proceeding

Nothing in this paragraph shall

of title 5

quote.#text: on the Board's own initiative or on complaint

text.#text: Section 11701(a) is amended by striking

quote.#text:
The Board may begin a proceeding under subsection (a)(1) on its own initiative or upon complaint,
			 except that a proceeding to determine the reasonableness of the level of a
			 rate charged by a carrier may only be initiated upon complaint.

text.#text: Section 10704(b) is amended by striking the first sentence and inserting

quote.#text:
on its activities, including each instance in which the Board has initiated an investigation on its
			 own initiative under this chapter or subtitle IV.

text.#text: Section 704 is amended by striking
Section 10701(d)(3) is amended to read as follows:

The Board shall maintain a simplified and expedited method for determining the reasonableness of
			 challenged rates in those cases in which a full stand-alone cost
			 presentation is too costly, given the value of the case.

quote.#text:
The Board shall maintain procedures to ensure expeditious handling of challenges to the
			 reasonableness of railroad rates.

text.#text: Section 10704(d) is amended by striking the first sentence and inserting
Section 10704(d), as amended by section 7 of this Act, is further amended—
by striking
by adding at the end the following:

Except as provided under subparagraph (B), in a stand-alone cost rate challenge, the Board shall
			 comply with the following timeline:
For discovery, completion not later than 150 days after the date that the challenge is initiated.

For development of the evidentiary record, completion not later than 155 days after the date that
			 discovery is complete under clause (i).

For submission of a closing brief, submission not later than  60 days after the date that
			 development of the evidentiary record is complete under clause (ii).

For a final Board decision, issuance not later than 180 days after the date that the last closing
			 brief is submitted under clause (iii).

The Board may extend a timeline under subparagraph (A) after a request from any party or in the
			 interest of due process.

Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Surface Transportation Board
			 shall initiate an ex parte proceeding on whether contract proposals for
			 multiple
			 origin-to-destination movements have adversely impacted the intent of
			 Congress that the Surface Transportation Board’s rate challenge procedures
			 remain available to shippers that are subject to railroad market
			 dominance, and how the Board can prevent such practices in the future.

Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Surface Transportation Board
			 shall report to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of
			 the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the
			 House of Representatives on—
whether current methodologies are sufficient to address the complexity of large rate cases; and
alternative methodologies that could streamline and expedite large rate cases.

header.#text: Arbitration of certain rail rates, practices, and common carrier service expectation disputes

text.#text: Chapter 117 is amended by adding at the end the following:

header.#text: Arbitration of certain rail rates, practices, and common carrier service disputes

short-title.#tail:
, the Board shall promulgate regulations to establish a binding arbitration process to resolve rail
			 rate, practice, and common carrier service
			 expectation complaints subject to the jurisdiction of the Board.
short-title.#text: Surface Transportation Board Reauthorization Act of 2014

text.#text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of the
The binding arbitration process—

shall apply to disputes involving rates, practices, and common carrier service expectations subject
			 to the jurisdiction of the Board; and
shall not apply to—

disputes to obtain the grant, denial, stay, or revocation of any license, authorization, or
			 exemption, or to prescribe for the future any conduct, rules, or results
			 of
			 general, industry-wide applicability, or to enforce a labor protective
			 condition; and
disputes solely between 2 or more rail carriers.
The Board—
may make the binding arbitration process available only to the relevant parties—
after the filing of a formal complaint; or

upon petition by a party at the conclusion of any informal dispute resolution process provided by
			 the Board for a complaint subject to this section;

with respect to rate disputes, may make the binding arbitration process available only to the
			 relevant parties if the rail carrier has market dominance, as determined
			 under section 10707 of this title; and

shall determine whether to pursue the binding arbitration process not later than 30 days after the
			 date that a petition or formal complaint is filed.

Initiation of the binding arbitration process shall preclude the Board from separately reviewing a
			 complaint or dispute related to the same rail rate, practice, or common
			 carrier
			 service expectation in a covered dispute involving the same parties.

In resolving a covered dispute involving the reasonableness of a rail carrier's rates, the
			 arbitrator or panel of arbitrators, as applicable, shall
			 consider the Board's methodologies for setting maximum lawful rates,
			 giving due consideration to the need for differential pricing to permit a
			 rail carrier to collect adequate revenues within the meaning of section
			 10704(a)(2).

In resolving a dispute involving  common carrier service expectations, the arbitrator or panel of
			 arbitrators, as applicable, shall
			 consider
			 the rates and service terms, and any
			 changes thereto, as published or otherwise made available under subsection
			 (b), (c), or (d) of section 11101.
Any decision reached in an arbitration process under this section—
shall—
be consistent with subtitle IV;
be in writing;
contain findings of fact and conclusions; and
be binding upon the parties; and
shall not have any precedential effect in any other or subsequent arbitration dispute.

An arbitrator or panel of arbitrators shall be selected not later than 14 days after the date of
			 the Board's decision to
			 initiate arbitration.

The evidentiary process of the binding arbitration process shall be completed not later than 90
			 days after
			 the date that the arbitration process is initiated, unless a party
			 requests an extension and the arbitrator or panel of arbitrators, as
			 applicable, grants it.

The arbitrator or panel of arbitrators, as applicable, shall issue a decision not later than 30
			 days after the date that the evidentiary
			 record is closed.

The Board may extend any of the timelines in this subsection upon the agreement of all parties in
			 the dispute.

Arbitration under this section shall be conducted by an arbitrator, or a panel of arbitrators,
			 selected from a roster,
			 maintained by the Board, of persons with rail transportation, economic
			 regulation, professional or business experience, including agriculture, in
			 the private sector.

If the parties cannot
			 mutually agree on an arbitrator, or the lead arbitrator of a panel of
			 arbitrators, the parties
			 shall select the arbitrator
			 or lead arbitrator from
			 the roster by alternately striking names from the roster until only 1 name
			 remains.

Notwithstanding subparagraph (A), each party to a dispute shall select 1 arbitrator from the
			 roster.

The parties to a dispute may mutually select 1 arbitrator from the roster to serve as the lead
			 arbitrator of the panel of arbitrators.
For purposes of this section, a panel of arbitrators shall be selected as follows:

The parties shall share the costs of the arbitration
			 equally.

An arbitral decision under this section may award the payment of damages or rate prescriptive
			 relief, but the
			 value of the award shall be limited as follows:
For common carrier service and practice disputes, the damage award may not exceed $2,000,000.

For rate disputes, the damage award, including any rate prescription, may not exceed $25,000,000,
			 and any rate prescription shall be limited to not longer than 5 years from
			 the date of the arbitral decision.

If a party appeals a decision under this section to the Board, the Board may review the decision
			 under
			 this section to determine if—
the decision is consistent with subtitle IV as applied by the Board; or
the award limitation under subsection (g).
The table of contents for chapter 117 is amended by adding at the end the following:

toc-entry.#text: 11709. Arbitration of certain rail rate, practice, and common carrier service disputes.

header.#text: Compilation of complaints at Surface Transportation Board

text.#text: Section 704, as amended by section 6 of this Act, is further amended—
by striking the section heading and inserting the following:
by inserting
by adding at the end the following:
The Board shall establish and maintain a database of complaints received by the Board.

The Board shall post a quarterly report of formal and informal service complaints received by the
			 Board during the previous quarter that includes—
a list of the type of each complaint;
the geographic region of each complaint; and
the resolution of each complaint, if appropriate.

The quarterly report may identify a complainant that submitted an informal complaint only upon the
			 written consent of the complainant.
Each quarterly report shall be posted on the Board's public website.

The table of contents for chapter 7 is amended by striking the item relating to section 704 and
			 inserting the following:

Not later than 60 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Surface Transportation Board
			 shall begin providing quarterly reports to the Committee on Commerce,
			 Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the
			 Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of
			 Representatives on the Surface Transportation Board's progress toward
			 addressing the issues raised in each unfinished regulatory proceeding,
			 regardless of whether the proceeding is subject to a statutory or
			 regulatory deadline.
It is the sense of Congress that—

the Surface Transportation Board should review the methodology employed to define the business
			 cycle in its annual
			 determination of revenue adequacy and consider undertaking, if necessary,
			 a rulemaking to define the business cycle;

as part of Docket No. EP 711, the Surface Transportation Board should consider if a rulemaking
			 proceeding on mandatory
			 competitive switching is needed to ensure a viable competitive national
			 rail system; and

if the Surface Transportation Board determines a rulemaking proceeding on mandatory competitive
			 switching is needed, the
			 Surface Transportation Board should ensure that such rulemaking is
			 completed in as timely a
			 manner as possible.
Section 705 is amended by striking paragraphs (1) through (3) and inserting the following:
$33,000,000 for fiscal year 2015;
$35,000,000 for fiscal year 2016;
$35,500,000 for fiscal year 2017;
$35,500,000 for fiscal year 2018; and
$36,000,000 for fiscal year 2019.

header.#text: Service of process in court proceedings

text.#text:
Nothing in this Act shall be construed to affect any suit commenced by or against the Surface
			 Transportation Board,	or any proceeding or challenge pending before the
			 Surface Transportation Board, prior to the date of enactment of this Act.

header.#text: Arbitration of certain rail rates, practices, and common carrier service expectation disputes

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

header.#text: Voluntary arbitration of certain rail rates, practices, and common carrier service disputes

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Surface Transportation Board Reauthorization Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Surface Transportation Board Reauthorization Act of 2014

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall promulgate regulations to establish a voluntary, but binding, arbitration process
			 to resolve rail
			 rate, practice, and common carrier service
			 expectation complaints subject to the jurisdiction of the

text.#text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of the
The binding arbitration process—
shall not apply to—

disputes to obtain the grant, denial, stay, or revocation of any license, authorization, or
			 exemption, or to prescribe for the future any conduct, rules, or results
			 of
			 general, industry-wide applicability, or to enforce a labor protective
			 condition; and
disputes solely between 2 or more rail carriers; and

shall not prevent parties from independently seeking or utilizing private arbitration services to
			 resolve any disputes they may have.
The
may make the voluntary, but binding, arbitration process available only to the relevant parties—
after the filing of a formal complaint;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: for a complaint subject to this section; or

text.#text:
upon petition by all parties at the conclusion of any informal dispute resolution process provided
			 by
			 the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to facilitate voluntary, but binding,

Any decision reached in an arbitration process under this section—

be in writing;

An arbitrator or panel of arbitrators shall be selected not later than 14 days after the date of

The evidentiary process of the binding arbitration process shall be completed not later than 90

The arbitrator or panel of arbitrators, as applicable, shall issue a decision not later than 30

text.#text:
Unless otherwise agreed by all of the parties, an arbitration under this section shall be conducted
			 by a panel of arbitrators,
			 selected from a roster,
			 maintained by the

If the parties cannot
			 mutually agree on an arbitrator, or the lead arbitrator of a panel of
			 arbitrators, the parties
			 shall select the arbitrator
			 or lead arbitrator from
			 the roster by alternately striking names from the roster until only 1 name
			 remains.

The parties to a dispute may mutually select 1 arbitrator from the roster to serve as the lead
			 arbitrator of the panel of arbitrators.

If the parties cannot mutually agree on a lead arbitrator, the parties shall select a lead
			 arbitrator using the process described in subparagraph (A).

In addition to the lead arbitrator selected under this subparagraph,  each party to a dispute shall
			 select 1 additional arbitrator from the
			 roster.
For purposes of this section, a panel of arbitrators shall be selected as follows:

The parties shall share the costs of the arbitration
			 equally.

An arbitral decision under this section may award the payment of damages or rate prescriptive
			 relief, but the
			 value of the award shall be limited as follows:
For common carrier service and practice disputes, the damage award may not exceed $2,000,000.

For rate disputes, the damage award, including any rate prescription, may not exceed $25,000,000,
			 and any rate prescription shall be limited to not longer than 5 years from
			 the date of the arbitral decision.

a clear abuse of arbitral authority or discretion occurred;
the decision directly contravenes statutory authority; or
the award limitation under subsection (g) was violated.
